\chapter{Introduction to SimSES}
\label{\detokenize{index:introduction-to-simses}}

\section{Introduction}
\label{\detokenize{introduction:introduction}}\label{\detokenize{introduction::doc}}
SimSES (Simulation of stationary energy storage systems) is an open source modeling framework for
simulating stationary energy storage systems. The tool, initially developed in MATLAB by Maik Naumann and
Nam Truong, was 2019 converted to Python and improved by Marc Moeller and Daniel Kucevic at the
Institute for Electrical Energy Storage Technology \sphinxhyphen{} Technical University Munich.

SimSES enables a detailed simulation and evaluation of stationary energy storage systems with the current main focus on
lithium\sphinxhyphen{}ion batteries. Future releases will include redox\sphinxhyphen{}flow batteries and Power\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}Gas systems.
The main component of the modular and flexible software\sphinxhyphen{}tool is an abstract approach to the
energy storage model, which allows the variation and hybridization of storage technologies and technical sub\sphinxhyphen{}components.
Furthermore, stress characterization enables the estimation of the energy storage degradation.
Various aging models can be used for this purpose, whereby detailed models based on aging
experiments especially for batteries had been developed at the Institute.
In order to optimize the utilization of the energy storage in the different applications,
a large number of operating strategies are implemented.
Time series simulations and built\sphinxhyphen{}in evaluations allow to calculate and monitor technical parameters for
simulated storage operation. Furthermore, technical and economic key performance indicators (characteristics)
are derived and enable the assessment and comparison of the simulation results.

The tool has been used for several publications, including the following papers:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Kucevic, D.; Tepe, B.; Englberger, S.; Parlikar, A.; Muehlbauer, M.; Bohlen, O.; Jossen, A.; Hesse, H. (2020); Standard Battery Energy Storage System Profiles: Analysis of various Applications for Stationary Lithium\sphinxhyphen{}Ion Battery Energy Storage Systems using a Holistic Simulation Framework, doi:10.1016/j.est.2019.101077

\item {} 
Naumann, M.; Truong, C. N.; Schimpe, M.; Kucevic, D.; Jossen, A.; Hesse, H., “SimSES: Software for techno\sphinxhyphen{}economic Simulation of Stationary Energy Storage Systems,” International ETG Congress 2017, Bonn, Germany, 2017, pp. 1\sphinxhyphen{}6.

\item {} 
Englberger, S.; Hesse, H.; Kucevic, D.; Jossen, A. A Techno\sphinxhyphen{}Economic Analysis of Vehicle\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}Building: Battery Degradation and Efficiency Analysis in the Context of Coordinated Electric Vehicle Charging 2019, 12, doi:10.3390/en12050955.

\item {} 
Naumann, M.; Karl, R.Ch.; Truong, C.N.; Jossen, A.; Hesse, H.C. (2015): Lithium\sphinxhyphen{}ion Battery Cost Analysis in PV\sphinxhyphen{}household Application. In: Energy Procedia 73, S. 37\sphinxhyphen{}47. DOI: 10.1016/j.egypro.2015.07.555.

\item {} 
Truong, C.; Naumann, M.; Karl, R.; Mueller, M.; Jossen, A.; Hesse, H. (2016): Economics of Residential Photovoltaic Battery Systems in Germany. The Case of Tesla’s Powerwall. In: Batteries 2 (2), S. 14\sphinxhyphen{}30. DOI: 10.3390/batteries2020014.

\end{itemize}

\section{Quickstart}
\label{\detokenize{quickstart:quickstart}}\label{\detokenize{quickstart::doc}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
Installation is only tested on Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
We plan to provide SimSES by PyPi package management in the future
\end{sphinxadmonition}

We recommend installing SimSES (and in general third\sphinxhyphen{}party) python packages in a
virtual environment, encapsulated from the system python distribution.
This is optional. To install SimSES in windows, it is currently recommended to use
\sphinxhref{https://www.anaconda.com/distribution/}{Anaconda}
and create a virtual environment (Python 3.6 or 3.7) with Anaconda. Creating a virtual environment with
Anaconda can be done within the Anaconda Navigator (Environments | Create) or via terminal.
A more deailed deocumentaion about virtual environment and how to create them can be found
\sphinxhref{https://docs.conda.io/projects/conda/en/latest/user-guide/tasks/manage-environments.html}{here}.


\subsection{Download and Configure SimSES Project}
\label{\detokenize{quickstart:download-and-configure-simses-project}}
After creating an virtula environment you can clone SimSES from servers hosted by the ‘leibniz rechenzentrum’.
You can easily clone (git) SimSES via: \sphinxurl{https://gitlab.lrz.de/ees-ses/opensimses}. After cloning SimSES you can
open the project within a Python IDE (e.g. \sphinxhref{https://www.jetbrains.com/pycharm/}{PyCharm}).
As project interpreter please select the before created virtual environment. In Pycharm this
can be done in Settings | ProjectInterpreter.

To start SimSES you have to install some required packages. This can be done by executing setup.py.
This installs the following packages:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
scipy

\item {} 
numpy

\item {} 
pandas

\item {} 
matplotlib

\end{itemize}

SimSES can be simply start with executing the main.py. This script starts the simulation as well as the
analysis with some basic settings. All possible settings as well as the code structure will be explained
in the following chapter.


\section{Basic structure of SimSES}
\label{\detokenize{basics:basic-structure-of-simses}}\label{\detokenize{basics::doc}}
SimSES is object\sphinxhyphen{}oriented programmed, which allows a modular combination of various components.
The core if SimSES is the storage system,
which is divided into an AC system and a DC system (see figure {\hyperref[\detokenize{basics:storage-system}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{AC storage system and DC Storage system in SimSES.}}}}). Each AC system
has one AC/DC converter at least one storage technology and one DC/DC converter. With SimSES
it is possible to simulate with more than one storage technology (AC coupled or DC coupled).
The selectable components a described in section configuration.

\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{SimSES_storageSystem}.pdf}
\caption{AC storage system and DC Storage system in SimSES.}\label{\detokenize{basics:id1}}\label{\detokenize{basics:storage-system}}\end{figure}


\section{Simulation Loop}
\label{\detokenize{basics:simulation-loop}}
SimSES is a time continuous simulation, which means that the calculations are done step by step.
The simulation loop is showed in figure {\hyperref[\detokenize{basics:simses-loop}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Simulation loop of SimSES.}}}} Based on the selected
operation strategy (application) the energy management system (EMS) calculates the AC target power.
The AC target power is splitted into the various AC systems. Within each AC system the power is
converted by a AC/DC converter and splitted into the various DC systems.

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{_source/simses.commons.config.generation:simses.commons.config.generation.simulation.SimulationConfigGenerator}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{SimulationConfigGenerator}}}
Bases: {\hyperref[\detokenize{_source/simses.commons.config.generation:simses.commons.config.generation.generator.ConfigGenerator}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{simses.commons.config.generation.generator.ConfigGenerator}}}}}

The SimulationConfigGenerator is a convenience class for generating a config for a SimSES simulation. Prior knowledge
of the options and structure of SimSES is recommended. Before using SimSES within another application it is very
helpful to get to know the concepts of SimSES by using it as a standalone tool.

This config generator allows the user to focus only on the options to generate as well as the systems to instantiate
without needing to worry about the config structure and naming. However, names of possible classes to instantiate
are necessary. Basic implementations like “No”\sphinxhyphen{}implementations are provided as convenience methods, other types
need to be named directly.

First, you generate options for different kind of components like housing, hvac, acdc / dcdc converter, etc.. For
all of these methods you get a return key for this kind of component. This key is needed for the instantiation methods.
Second, you define the AC and DC systems with the keys defined and some other values like max. AC power, capacity and
intermediate circuit voltage.

You are able to load configs (defaults, local, or your own config file). Please consider that maybe AC and DC systems
are already defined which will be instantiated. You can clear these options with the provided clear functions.

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{_source/simses.commons.config:simses.commons.config.abstract_config.Config}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{Config}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{path}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{name}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{config}}}{}
Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{abc.ABC}}

The Config class contains all necessary configuration options of a package, e.g. simulation or analysis. In addition,
the Config class selects proper options from defaults, local or in code configurations. For all sections of each
config a own config class is provided and is inherited from Config.

Configs are taken from INI files in config package. {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}.defaults.ini are read in first, followed by {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}.local.ini and
finally overwritten by a ConfigParser passed in as a constructor argument. This threefold delivers functionality by
default if you just want to run a possible setup. If a specific simulation should be run locally, the config parameters
of the {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}.local.ini file will overwrite the configuration of defaults; only necessary parameters can be included in
the local config file. Furthermore, for sensitivity analysis the ConfigParser argument is taken into account to
automate various configurations. The ConfigParser should have the same structure as the config files and overwrites
the given values.

Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}

FileProfile is able to read time series from a file. It supports several unit and date formats, takes timezones into
consideration (default: Berlin) and interpolates respectively averages values of the given time series. If no time series
is given, a time generator generates the timestep according to the given sampling rate or simulation timestep.

A header could inherit the given timezone, value unit, time unit and sampling rate:

\# Unit: W

\# Timezone: Berlin

\# Time: s

\# Sampling in s: 3600s

Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{abc.ABC}}

Basic abstract class for all states in SimSES. States in SimSES are date objects 1) transfering data from one
object to another and 2) documenting results of simulation. Those written state files are used for the analysis
of the simulation. There are no cached results in SimSES, all states are written immediately after each simulation
timestep. The underlying state object in this class is a plain dictonary.

BatchProcessing delivers the necessary handling for running multiple parallel SimSES simulations and distributes
the configuration to each process. It supervises all processes and starts as many processes as there are cores
available. If you run more simulations than cores available, it waits until a simulation has finished and fills
the gap with new simulation processes.

StorageSimulation constructs the the storage systems and energy management system in order to execute the simulation.
In the run() method the timestamp for the simulation is advanced as configured. Alternatively, simulation is included
in another framework advancing timestamps itself, e.g. run\_one\_step() or evaluate\_multiple\_steps(). StorageSimulation
also provided information of the current status of the simulation to the user.

power.

Bases: {\hyperref[\detokenize{_source/simses.logic.energy_management.strategy:simses.logic.energy_management.strategy.operation_strategy.OperationStrategy}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{simses.logic.energy\_management.strategy.operation\_strategy.OperationStrategy}}}}}

Operation strategy for providing FCR. It was developed according to the German regulatory framework .
The requested charging and discharging power is proportional to the frequency deviation.
Below 49.8 Hz or above 50.2 Hz the output power is set to the prequalified power. Within the frequency dead band
around 50 Hz with +/\sphinxhyphen{}10 mHz the output power is set to 0 W. The degree of freedom to exceed the output power by a
factor of 1.2 is used aiming to bring the SOC back to a predefined SOC set point.

TechnologyBasedPowerDistributor distributes the power depend on the current state and storage technology used.
A priority list for the technology is used for the order of execution. In addition, TechnologyBasedPowerDistributor
tries to rebalance the SOC of the various storage devices if possible.

Hydrogen is the top level class for coordinating all technologies related to hydrogen, i.e. electrolyzer, fuel cells
and storage tank. It provides a management system for taking limitations into consideration. The hydrogen class
requires always an electrolyzer, a fuel cell and a storage. In cases this circle is unwanted, dummy classes
exists doing nothing, e.g. NoElectrolyzer or NoFuelCell.

\begin{enumerate}

Having static max / min values for current and voltage or dynamic for each battery type and state?

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{} Not needed anymore
\begin{enumerate}

\setcounter{enumi}{1}
\item {} 
How to calculate the equilibrium balancing current between batteries?

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{} Calculate balancing current depending on OCV an internal resistence of each battery
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{)}%
\setcounter{enumi}{2}
\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{How to avoid divergency for specific LIB types? Are LIB types correctly modelled? Why do some work, others dont?}] \leavevmode
Working: PanasonicNCA, MolicelNMC, SanyoNMC, AkasolAkmNMC;
Not working: SonyLFP, GenericCell, AkasolOemNMC;

\end{description}

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{} All battery types should work
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{)}%
\setcounter{enumi}{3}
\item {} 
Current alogrithm works better with higher capacities / lower C\sphinxhyphen{}Rates

\item {} 
Right now the overall current is split between the batteries depending on their capacities. One way to a faster voltage convergence could be to only discharge the battery with higher voltage and charge only the battery with a lower voltage with the applied current.

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{} Current is split depending on OCV and internal resistance, in the same function which also calculate the balance currents
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{)}%
\setcounter{enumi}{5}
\item {} 
During the balancing process batteries partly cannot handle the balancing current, hence it takes time for converging \sphinxhyphen{} in standard simulation around 30 min.

\end{enumerate}
\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{} If batteries can not handle the balancing current or overall current (BMS is limiting), the BMS would open the circuit breakers to protect the batterie from overcurrent.}] \leavevmode
If this happens, the scenario is not feasable.

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{_source/simses.technology.redox_flow:simses.technology.redox_flow.system.RedoxFlow.convection_coefficient}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{property }}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{convection\_coefficient}}}
Convective heat transfer coefficient of a redox flow battery.

A value of 5 W/m\textasciicircum{}2/K is assumed for the convective heat transfer coefficient, which is in the same order of
magnitude as the reported values from Tang et al. (2012) and Yan et al. (2016).
If the thermal model is to be used for a particular redox flow battery geometry, the value must be adjusted with
respect to the system specifications.
Tang, Ao, et al. “Thermal modelling and simulation of the all\sphinxhyphen{}vanadium redox flow battery.” Journal of Power
Sources 203 (2012): 165\sphinxhyphen{}176.
Yan, Yitao, et al. “Modelling and simulation of thermal behaviour of vanadium redox flow battery.” Journal of
Power Sources 322 (2016): 116\sphinxhyphen{}128.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
float

\end{description}\end{quote}

Calculates the cashflow for each project year that is generated by the given RevenueStream.
A RevenueStream can be seen as the financial impact of the various applications of a BESS such as peak shaving,
self\sphinxhyphen{}consumption, frequency containment reserve, etc..

Converts a cashflow time series for every timestep to a cashflow time series for every project year.
A project year is assumed to be 365 days long. A full leap year would therefore be one project year and one day.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{cashflows}} \textendash{} List of float, representing cashflow for each timestep

\item {} 
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{time}} \textendash{} List of float, unix timestamps for each simulation step

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
List of float, representing cashflow for each project year.

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
list of float

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}

StorageAnalysis conducts the analysis of the simulated storage systems by SimSES. For each storage technology as
well as for each (sub)system key performance indicators (KPI) are generated and time series are plotted. All
information is merged into a HTML file which opens in the standard browser after analysis is finished. The analysis
is configured by analysis.ini in the config package. Additionally, KPIs for comparison between multiple simulations
are written to file in batch folder located in results path.
